subject: RE: [junit] Junit Version4.0
msgSnippet: Anjali, We don t have a concrete release date. The big variable at this point is the runner architecture. We are happy with the annotation-based interface, so

Anjali,

We don't have a concrete release date. The big variable at this po=
int is the
runner architecture. We are happy with the annotation-based inte=
rface, so
that part (org.junit.*) shouldn't change much. Designing the API =
for
specifying and running tests (org.junit.runner.*) is proving more diffi=
cult
(as it was in JUnit <4).

Would having a concrete release date help yo=
u?

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> Message:=
 1            Date: Fri, 24 Jun 2005 12:24:17 -0000
>    From: "arnabgupta2=
000" <arnabgupta2000@...>
> Subject: Testing API where order in which=
 methods are invoked matters
> 
> Hello,
> 
> I am new to JUnit and in need=
 for a solution. I have written a
> library of which I need to test one cla=
ss. The methods 
> exposed by this class cannot be called randomly but by 
=
> following some rules. For example, there is a method 
> "Connect" which m=
ust be invoked before any other method is 
> called. There are additional c=
alls that are related. For 
> example "ChangeHeaders" makes temporary chang=
e to some data 
> (after some business logic verification), however this mu=
st 
> be followed by a call to "SaveChanges" to persist this data. 
> Whate=
ver I have read
> about JUnit seems to indicate that the test methods in my=
 
> test class can be called in any order by the JUnit framework. 
> Is the=
re any way (a pattern) to get around this issue ? 
> Thanks much in advance=
..
> 
> Regards,
> Arnab.
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

> Message: 2          =
  Date: Thu, 23 Jun 2005 15:46:02 -0700
>    From: Michael Giroux <mlgiroux=
@...>
> Subject: JUNITREPORT ANT Task Suggestion
> 
> Not sure if thi=
s is the correct place to post this, let me know if I
> shouold post to Apa=
che ANT list.
> 
> The ANT JunitReport task includes all properties that we=
re defined at
> the time of the test.  If any of these properties contain s=
ecurity
> information (userid, password, ...) that was needed for any part =
of
> the overall build, these values become public information when the
> J=
unitReport is published.
> 
> Suggestion:
> JunitReport should take a neste=
d element, perhaps regular expressions,
> that allow the developer to filte=
r/remove individual properties so
> they do not appear in the generated HTM=
L documents.
> 
> Current Avoidance:
> I'm using <replaceregexp> ANT task t=
o modify the input xml 
> files for now.
> 
> Michael Giroux
> 
> 
> 
>

rom: "raycclough" <ray@...>
> Subject: Using a Special Class =
Loader to test a Singleton
> 
> I know that the JUnit community frowns on S=
ingletons.  However I have
> a piece of code which uses a singleton, and I =
want to test it.  The
> singleton takes a "Reader" in it's constructor (whi=
ch may be null, and
> then it uses a properties file to create its data).  =
I want to test it
> using various different data sets.  In line with that, =
I created a
> custom Class Loader, and use Reflection to create the object.=
  It
> works great (except, of course, where it doesn't).  The reflexively
=
> obtained constructor returns an object of type 'Object', which the
> debu=
gger says has the correct underlying type, and it contains the
> correct da=
ta, but I cannot Cast it to the type it needs to be.  Any
> hint to what I'=
m doing wrong?  Thanks for any advice you can give me
> on this.
> 
> Here'=
s the relevant code from the JUnit 'setUp()' method:
>  //////// start code=
 try {
>     // since the Controller is a singleton, and may have been load=
ed
>     // before with different set-up data, use a ClassLoader to
>     /=
/ create a new instance of it.  This requires using Java
>     // Reflectio=
n to instantiate the object.  If we just called
>     // "classForName()", =
the system class loader would be asked to
>     // return any previously lo=
aded instance of the class.  Since
>     // this is what we want to avoid, =
a special ClassLoader returns
>     // a new instance of the class.
>     S=
pecialClassLoader loader =3D new SpecialClassLoader();
>     Class ctlrClas=
s =3D loader.findClass(		 
"rdyne_rdcs.comm_gateway.controller.DefaultGatew=
ayController");
> 							     // 
> instantiate the controller using reflec=
tion
>     Class[] paramTypes =3D { Reader.class };
>     Object[] args =3D=
 {reader};    // contains the "test data"
> 		     Constructor constructor =
=3D 
> ctlrClass.getDeclaredConstructor(paramTypes);
>     constructor.setA=
ccessible(true);
>     Object o =3D constructor.newInstance(args);
> 		    =
 //Method m =3D 
> ctlrClass.getMethod("getController",paramTypes);
>     /=
/m.setAccessible(true);
>     //Object o =3D m.invoke(null,args);
> 		 // T=
ODO  - Figure this out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> // unfortunately somehow the Obj=
ect may not be cast to the required
> // class "DefaultGatewayController", =
or even to its interface.
> // This is true whether the "Constructor" metho=
d or the "Method"
> // method is used.  
>     if ( DefaultGatewayControlle=
r.class.isInstance(o) ) {
>         // "o" may safely be cast as a "Default=
GatewayController"
> 	System.out.println("YOWSA");
> 	ctlr =3D (DefaultGate=
wayController)o;
>     } else {
> 	System.out.println("OHNO");
> 	System.ou=
t.println("Class: " + o.getClass().getName());
>     }
> 
> } catch (ClassN=
otFoundException cnfe) {
> 	cnfe.printStackTrace();
> } catch (NoSuchMethod=
Exception nsme) {
> 	nsme.printStackTrace();
> } catch (IllegalAccessExcept=
ion iae) {
> 	iae.printStackTrace();
> } catch (InvocationTargetException i=
te) {
> 	ite.printStackTrace();
> } catch (InstantiationException ie) {
> 	=
ie.printStackTrace(); } catch (ClassCastException cce) {
> 	cce.printStackT=
race();
> }
> 
> //////// end code
> 
> This always goes thru the "OHNO" br=
anch, although the output of the
> class name is what it should be to allow=
 me to cast it.  I'm fairly
> new to JUnit, and I'm really new to custom Cl=
ass Loaders, but it seems
> to me that this should work easily and well.  T=
hanks,
> - Ray Clough

in it's constructor (which may

s file to create its data).  I want

nt data sets.  In line with that, I created a

use Reflection to create the object.  It

bject of type 'Object', which the

ing type, and it contains the

 type it needs to be.  Any

y advice you can give me

> > > Here's the relevant code from t=
he JUnit 'setUp()' method:

> 
> >     //=
 since the Controller is a singleton, and may have been loaded
> >     // b=
efore with different set-up data, use a ClassLoader to

new instance of it.  This requires using Java

antiate the object.  If we just called

tem class loader would be asked to
> >     // return any previously loaded =
instance of the class.  Since

pecial ClassLoader returns
> >     // a new instance of the class.
> >     =
SpecialClassLoader loader =3D new SpecialClassLoader();
> >     Class ctlrC=
lass =3D loader.findClass(		 > 
> "rdyne_rdcs.comm_gateway.controller.Defau=
ltGatewayController");
> > 							 >     
> // instantiate the controller u=
sing reflection
> >     Class[] paramTypes =3D { Reader.class };
> >     Ob=
ject[] args =3D {reader};    // contains the "test data"
> > 		 >     Const=
ructor constructor =3D > 
> ctlrClass.getDeclaredConstructor(paramTypes);
>=
 >     constructor.setAccessible(true);
> >     Object o =3D constructor.ne=
wInstance(args);
> 
> If you are going to use reflection to defeat the priv=
ate 
> constructor, why bother reloading the class.
> 
> > 		 >     //Metho=
d m =3D 
> ctlrClass.getMethod("getController",paramTypes);
> >     //m.set=
Accessible(true);
> >     //Object o =3D m.invoke(null,args);
> > 		 > // T=
ODO  - Figure this out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

bject may not be cast to the required
> > // class "DefaultGatewayControlle=
r", or even to its interface.
> > // This is true whether the "Constructor"=
 method or the "Method"
> > // method is used.  > >     if ( 
> DefaultGate=
wayController.class.isInstance(o) ) {
> >         // "o" may safely be cast=
 as a "DefaultGatewayController"
> > 	System.out.println("YOWSA");
> > 	ctl=
r =3D (DefaultGatewayController)o;
> 
> The problem is that "DefaultGateway=
Controller.class" is not 
> the same instance as ctlrClass. Although if 
> =
DefaultGatewayController had an interface I would expect you 
> to be able =
to cast it to that.
> 
> >     } else {
> > 	System.out.println("OHNO");
> =
> 	System.out.println("Class: " + o.getClass().getName());
> >     }

>=
 snipped exception handling - why not just declare the test as 
> throws Ex=
ception.
> 
> > This always goes thru the "OHNO" branch, although the outpu=
t of the
> > class name is what it should be to allow me to cast it.  I'm f=
airly
> > new to JUnit, and I'm really new to custom Class Loaders, 
> but =
it seems
> > to me that this should work easily and well.  Thanks,
> > - Ra=
y Clough
> > ray@...
> > 
> There are 2 solutions:
> 1) load =
the entire junit test using your special classloader. 
> This is not easy.
=
> 
> 2) Invoke the methods on ctlr using reflection.
> 
> In the files sect=
ion I submitted an example of a 
> classreloader. JB Rainsberger's JUnit Re=
cipes also contains a 
> recipe on this subject.
> 
> I have since come up =
with a much simpler version of the 
> reloader that you can find in my JIso=
late project:
> http://sourceforge.net/projects/jisolate
> 
> No release av=
aliable yet but if you pull the project from cvs 
> into eclipse you may ge=
t some ideas.
> 
> - Neil

> Message: 7            Date: Tue,=
 28 Jun 2005 09:52:50 +0100
>    From: Chris Dollin <kers@...>
=
> Subject: Re: Testing API where order in which methods are 
> invoked matt=
ers
> 
> On Friday 24 June 2005 13:24, arnabgupta2000 wrote:
> > Hello,
> >=

> > I am new to JUnit and in need for a solution. I have written a
> > lib=
rary
> > of which I need to test one class. The methods exposed by this cla=
ss
> > cannot be called randomly but by following some rules. For example,
=
> > there is a method "Connect" which must be invoked before any other
> > =
method is called. There are additional calls that are related. For
> > exam=
ple "ChangeHeaders" makes temporary change to some data (after
> > some bus=
iness logic verification), however this must be 
> followed by a
> > call t=
o "SaveChanges" to persist this data. Whatever I have read
> > about
> > JU=
nit seems to indicate that the test methods in my test 
> class can be
> > =
called in any order by the JUnit framework. Is there any way (a
> > pattern=
) to get around this issue ? Thanks much in advance..
> 
> Yes, the methods=
 in your test class are not (necessarily) called
> in any particular order.=
 This is a feature. Each test method should
> be unrelated to the others - =
otherwise it's too hard to eg move
> them around for greater expressivity, =
call only the failing when
> when you want to isolate a problem, &co.
> 
> =
There are at least two things you can do:
> 
> (a) Ensure that each test us=
es its own object (easy) and that it
>     runs the piece of lifecycle you'=
re interested in to     
> completion.
> 
> (b) Refactor so that this objec=
t-state dependency is reduced
>     (preferably to zero).
> 
> For (b) I'd =
start by fixing the `connect` problem: if nothing
> can be done withotu a c=
onnection, I'd have a more factory-like
> object with a `connect` method; c=
alling this delivers a connected
> object.
> 
> For Change/Save, I'd just h=
ave the test do the Change and then
> the Save in the same testXXX() method=
.
> 
> -- Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
> It's called *extreme* programm=
ing, not *stupid* programming.
> 
> 
> 
> _________________________________=
_____________________________
> __________
> ______________________________=
________________________________
> __________
> 
> Message: 8            Da=
te: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 10:00:37 +0100
>    From: Andrew McDonagh <andrew.mcdo=
nagh@...>
> Subject: Re: Using a Special Class Loader to test a Si=
ngleton
> 
> raycclough wrote:
> 
> >I know that the JUnit community frowns=
 on Singletons.  However I have
> >a piece of code which uses a singleton, =
and I want to test it.  The
> >singleton takes a "Reader" in it's construct=
or (which may be 
> null, and
> >then it uses a properties file to create i=
ts data).  I want 
> to test it
> >using various different data sets.  In l=
ine with that, I created a
> >custom Class Loader, and use Reflection to cr=
eate the object.  It
> >works great (except, of course, where it doesn't). =
 The reflexively
> >obtained constructor returns an object of type 'Object'=
, which the
> >debugger says has the correct underlying type, and it contai=
ns the
> >correct data, but I cannot Cast it to the type it needs to be.  A=
ny
> >hint to what I'm doing wrong?  Thanks for any advice you can give me
=
> >on this.
> >
> >  >
> 
> snipped code.
> 
> I take it you want to do som=
e kind of reset of the singleton 
> so that you can test different datasets=
?
> 
> If so, forget about classloading, reflection, etc and keep it simple=
.
> 
> A number of options are available all...
> 
> 1) just add a public i=
nstance method to reset the reader and 
> anything else of the singleton:
>=
 
> class DefaultGatewayController {
>     public static DefaultGatewayCont=
roller getInstance() {
>        return s_instance;
>     }
> 
>    public v=
oid resetReader(Reader r) {
>         ....
> 
>    }
> }
> 
> 2) Hide the r=
eset methods behind an interface. Move the 
> Singleton implementation behi=
nd an interface and a test 
> interface.  The getInstance() method return t=
ype would be the 
> standard interface, but your tests can cast to the 
> t=
estInterface to get access to the reset methods.
> 
> class GatewayControll=
erSingleton {
>      private static GatewayController s_instance;
> 
>     =
public static GatewayController  getInstance() {
>         if (s_instance !=
=3D null) {
>             s_instance =3D new DefaultGatewayController();
> =
       }
> 
>         return s_instance;
>     }
> 
> }
> 
> interface Gate=
wayController {
> ...
> }
> 
> 
> interface TestableGatewayController {
>  =
  void resetReader(Reader r);
> }
> 
> 
> class DefaultGatewayController im=
plements GatewayController, 
> TestableGatewayController{
> ...
> }
> 
> Pl=
us some other approaches....
> 
> HTH
> 
> Andrew
> 
>

> Message:=
 9            Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 11:32:38 +0200 (MEST)
>    From: "Hara=
ld Mueller" <harald.m.mueller@...>
> Subject: quite OT: Building a =
system test group
> 
> Hi all -
> 
> forgive me for this OT posting - but I=
 hope that you can shed 
> light on that
> topic; and/or send me to a more =
appropriate community. Thx!
> (I asked on softwaretestingexperts@yahoogroup=
s, but this is 
> more sort of a
> job listing group).
>

> Message: 10           Da=
te: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 12:42:04 -0000
>    From: "Jeff Grigg" <jeffgrigg@char=
ter.net>
> Subject: Re: Using a Special Class Loader to test a Singleton
> =

> --- "raycclough" <ray@a...> wrote:
> > [...], I created a custom Class L=
oader, and use Reflection to
> > create the object.  It works great (except=
, of course, where
> > it doesn't).  The reflexively obtained constructor r=
eturns an
> > object of type 'Object', which the debugger says has the
> > =
correct underlying type, and it contains the correct data,
> > but I cannot=
 Cast it to the type it needs to be.  Any hint
> > to what I'm doing wrong?=
  Thanks for any advice you can give
> > me on this.
> 
> To directly answe=
r your question:  You can't cast the object 
> because it was created under=
 a different class loader.  You 
> can only interact with that class throug=
h reflection.  You 
> can't cast it to types or interfaces -- unless those =
classes 
> were loaded by a common class loader -- IE: the system class loa=
der.
> 
> I worked around this recently by loading the TestCase class 
> it=
self under the new class loader and calling the current 
> test method on t=
he new instance, using reflection.  (And 
> setting a flag so that the new =
instance knew it was running 
> under the new class loader.)
> 
> A bit mor=
e detail:  The "type" of an instance, its 
> identification, is the class n=
ame *PLUS* the the address of 
> the ClassLoader instance that loaded it.  =
That's how web 
> servers keep applications separate from each other: They =

> create one ClassLoader instance for each logical application 
> "process=
" they want to keep separate.
> 
> Question:
> Since you're already using '=
.setAccessible(true)' already, 
> why not use reflection to replace the sta=
tic singleton instance field?
> 
> > [...]
> >     SpecialClassLoader loade=
r =3D new SpecialClassLoader();
> >     Class ctlrClass =3D loader.findClas=
s(		 > 
> "rdyne_rdcs.comm_gateway.controller.DefaultGatewayController");
>=
 > 							 >     
> // instantiate the controller using reflection
> >     =
Class[] paramTypes =3D { Reader.class };
> >     Object[] args =3D {reader}=
;    // contains the "test data"
> > 		 >     Constructor constructor =3D >=
 
> ctlrClass.getDeclaredConstructor(paramTypes);
> >     constructor.setAc=
cessible(true);
> >     Object o =3D constructor.newInstance(args);
> > 		 =
>     //Method m =3D 
> ctlrClass.getMethod("getController",paramTypes);
> =
>     //m.setAccessible(true);
> >     //Object o =3D m.invoke(null,args);
=
> > 		 > // TODO  - Figure this out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> > // unfortunately =
somehow the Object may not be cast to the required
> > // class "DefaultGat=
ewayController", or even to its interface.
> > // This is true whether the =
"Constructor" method or the "Method"
> > // method is used.  > >     if ( 
=
> DefaultGatewayController.class.isInstance(o) ) {
> >         // "o" may s=
afely be cast as a "DefaultGatewayController"
> > 	System.out.println("YOWS=
A");
> > 	ctlr =3D (DefaultGatewayController)o;
> >     } else {
> > 	Syste=
m.out.println("OHNO");
> > 	System.out.println("Class: " + o.getClass().get=
Name());
> >     }
> > [...]
> > > This always goes thru the "OHNO" branch,=
 although the output
> > of the class name is what it should be to allow me=
 to cast it.
> > I'm fairly new to JUnit, and I'm really new to custom Clas=
s
> > Loaders, but it seems to me that this should work easily and
> > well=
. [...]

> Message: 12           Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 06:56:=
06 -0700
>    From: "Cedric Beust" <cbeust@...>
> Subject: RE: Testi=
ng API where order in which methods are 
> invoked matters
> 
> > From: jun=
it@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] 
> On > Behalf Of Chris D=
ollin
> 
> > Yes, the methods in your test class are not (necessarily) > 
>=
 called in any particular order. This is a feature. Each test 
> > method s=
hould be unrelated to the others - otherwise it's 
> too > hard to eg move =
them around for greater expressivity, 
> call > only the failing when when =
you want to isolate a problem, &co.
> 
> I don't see why it's too hard to d=
o that:  the framework will always
> guarantee that the methods are invoked=
 in the right order and 
> that dependent
> methods will always be invoked =
before.
> 
> Anyway, the short answer to the original question is that 
> o=
rdering testing
> methods is not covered by unit testing, and if you want t=
o do 
> this, you are
> probably doing more than unit testing (and you shou=
ld therefore use
> http://testng.org :-)).
>  > For (b) I'd start by fixing=
 the `connect` problem: if 
> nothing > can be done withotu a connection, I=
'd have a more > 
> factory-like object with a `connect` method; calling th=
is > 
> delivers a connected object.
> 
> If this object is expensive to ge=
t, it would be nice to save 
> it in-between
> invocations, which brings us=
 back to maintaining state and 
> ordering methods.
> 
> -- C=E9dric
> http=
://beust.com/weblog
> 
>
